Selecting appropriate catalysts to reduce CO2 into C1 and C2 products can effectively alleviate the greenhouse effect. In this work, the catalytic reduction of CO2 on the single Cu atom adsorbed Janus MoSSe monolayer is studied by using DFT calculations. Two electron reduction of CO2 usually yields two products of CO and HCOOH. The adsorption of a single Cu atom on Janus MoSSe monolayer induces the decrease of the band gap and the paramagnetism arising from the copper 3d orbital contribution, which may prompt the catalytic reduction of CO2. Meanwhile, the unique internal electric field due to the novel asymmetric structure of MoSSe and the enhancement (by about 17%) of the local electric field in MoSSe-Cu could significantly accelerate the carrier movement and separation, reflecting the good electrocatalytic performances of MoSSe-Cu system. Here, MoSSe-Cu is more favorable to catalyze the direct reduction of CO2 to HCOOH, with the free energy of merely 0.49 eV for the rate-determining step, indicating that MoSSe-Cu may act as the potential catalyst for reduction of CO2 to HCOOH. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Janus MoSSe Copper adsorption CO2 reduction reaction Density function theory (DFT) Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 exhibits high efficiency, fast speed, mild reaction conditions and high product selectivity, which has become a hot research topic in carbon reduction conversion and utilization at home and abroad [1–3]. Copper is a well-known electrocatalyst for CO2RR, and there has been an increasing interest in the development of copper based nanocatalysts in recent years [4–6]. Cu-based materials exhibit excellent activity and selectivity to reduce CO2 into hydrocarbons such as methanol, methane, formic acid [7], ethylene, etc [8]. In these products, formic acid is usually regarded as a promising hydrogen storage material, important chemical feedstock, and liquid fuel for fuel cells [9]. Unfortunately, traditional copper based electrocatalysts have the shortcomings of low selectivity and conversion, which considerably depress their practical applications [10,11]. Therefore, it is critical and urgent to design and develop the copper based electrocatalysts with enhanced catalytic properties so as to meet the increasing demands [12–14]. Among the relevant studies on copper based electrocatalysts, the focus is the novel electrocatalysts with the substrates of two-dimensional materials. Shi et al. firstly established the Cu-C chemical bond via rational design of in situ anchoring of Cu single atoms on the unique platform graphdiyne, which facilitates the reduction of CO2 to CH4 [15]. Chen et al. realized N-heterocyclic carbine ligated copper single atom site embedded metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and achieved an outstanding Faradaic efficiency for CO2 reduction to CH4 [16]. Zhao et al. designed single atom copper encapsulated N-doped porous carbon (Cu-SA/NPC) catalysts for reducing CO2 to multi-carbon products [17]. Wang et al. constructed CuN/MoS2/Ag(111) heterostructures as prototypical examples and theoretically established the concept of the dynamically magic single-cluster catalyst for high-efficient selective hydrogenation of CO2 to CH3OH [18]. The catalytic performance of Cu could be significantly improved by using two-dimensional materials as substrates. In recent years, a unique asymmetrical two-dimensional material, Janus MoSSe, has also attracted extensive interest of researches [19–21]. This novel material can be experimentally synthesized from the original symmetrical MoS2 by replacing the S atoms of the upper layer by Se atoms [22]. Owing to its unique asymmetry of the structural property, Janus MoSSe monolayer has been found to exhibit good catalytic performances for NRR, OER and other reactions [23–26], largely attributable to the intrinsic electrical field arising from the structural asymmetry. Interesting studies have been performed for the catalytic preparation of CO and NH3 on some transition metal (TM) atoms adsorbed Janus MoSSe systems [23,27–29]. However, there are few researches on the catalytic CO2RR performances of TM single atom modified Janus MoSSe monolayer, especially Cu adsorbed systems for the catalytic preparation of formic acid, an important and fundamental industrial source, from CO2RR. Therefore, present study on the single Cu atom absorbed Janus MoSSe monolayer would demonstrate great scientific and practical significance for catalytic reduction of CO2 and may prompt the further exploration of novel highly-efficient copper based electrocatalysts for reduction of CO2 to HCOOH. 2 Calculation method The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [30,31]. The energy band, density of states and Gibbs free energy correction were used by Vaspkit [32]. The exchange-correlation potential was described by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the scheme of Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) [33]. A 4 × 4 supercell was chosen, and the vacuum layer thickness of 20 Å along the Z-direction was added to avoid the interaction between the Janus MoSSe monolayer. The cut-off energy of 500 eV was set for the plane wave basis, as conducted in various studies [23,34–36]. The geometric convergence criteria for energy and force were set as 10−5 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. A 6 × 6 × 1 Gamma-centered Monkhorst-Pack k-point grids were adopted to conduct geometry optimization and electronic structure calculations. The spin polarization calculations were used to compute the adsorption of Cu atom and CO2 molecule. Considering the van der Waals (vdW) interaction between TM atoms, Janus MoSSe monolayers and gas molecules, the zero-damped DFT-D3 method is adopted for vdW correction [37]. In addition, the adsorption energy Eads of Cu atom or CO2 molecule on the substrate of Janus MoSSe monolayer can be calculated from the following equation: (1) E a d s = E A B − E A − E B where A represents Cu or CO2, and B stands for MoSSe or Cu-MoSSe. Gibbs free energy G of the reactions for CO2RR and HER elementary steps involving (H + + e− ) pair transfer was calculated by using the computational hydrogen electrode model [38,39]. At electron potential of zero (versus the reversible hydrogen electrode), the free energy difference (ΔG) of each state could be obtained from the following equation [40–43]: (2) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S where T is the absolute temperature, which is set as 298.15 K [44]. E is the electronic energy, which is obtained by DFT calculation. Δ S and Δ E Z P E are the changes of entropy and zero-point energy (ZPE), respectively, which can be acquired from the vibration frequency calculations by using Vaspkit [32]. The process of HER can be expressed as H + + e− → H* and H* → 1/2 H2. The free energy of H + + e− is the same as that of 1/2 H2 under standard conditions of equilibrium [45]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of Janus MoSSe monolayer The structure of Janus MoSSe monolayer is similar to that of MoS2 monolayer, containing Se, Mo and S atomic layers from top to bottom. Dipole correction was adopted in the structural optimization of Janus MoSSe monolayer and the relevant systems. The original energy without dipole correction was −342.37446368 eV, while that with dipole correction turned out to be −342.36934109 eV, as shown in Fig. S1, yielding the tiny difference of −0.00512259 eV. Considering that the error due to the neglecting of dipole correction is actually very small, the dipole correction was only added in the subsequent electrostatic potential calculations. After structure optimization, the lattice constant is a = b = 3.23 Å, with the distance of 3.24 Å between the atomic layers of the upper surface Se and the lower surface S as well as the Mo-S and Mo-Se bond lengths of 2.41 and 2.53 Å, respectively. These values are consistent with the previous studies [20,21] and could be regarded as reasonable. The magnetic moment of Janus MoSSe monolayer is 0 μB, indicating the non-magnetic nature of this material. 3.2 Cu adsorbed Janus MoSSe monolayer In order to determine the optimal adsorption sites, all configurations were structurally optimized. According to Eq. (1), the adsorption energy of Cu single atom adsorbed on Janus MoSSe monolayer is calculated and listed in Fig. 1 . The adsorption energy of the S-side site is lower than that of the Se side, and the Mo top of the S-side has the lowest adsorption energy among the six adsorption sites, which is the best adsorption site for single Cu atom on Janus MoSSe monolayer. This point may be suitably illustrated from the significant difference in electronegativity between Mo and Cu atoms on each side of the S atoms, as supported by the previous investigation [23]. The negative adsorption energy indicates that the metal atoms tend to adsorb separately at the corresponding sites on the substrate rather than clustering together [46]. And the previous work [24] for noble metals (Pd, Pt and Ir) adsorption on MoSSe also revealed that two transition metal atoms are more likely to adsorb separately than to cluster together. From the above analysis, Cu atoms would not aggregate to form clusters on the surface of Janus MoSSe. As shown in Fig. 1, the Mo-top site with the lowest adsorption energy for Cu on MoSSe monolayer is selected for the subsequent studies. The original band gap of MoSSe is 1.63 eV, as shown in Fig. 2 (a), in good agreement with the experimental value (≈ 1.68 eV) [22]. From the band structure diagram of MoSSe-Cu in Fig. 2(b), the band gap is almost the same as the pure Janus MoSSe, merely slightly reduced by 0.02 eV, exhibiting the similar semiconductor behavior to the pristine system. After the adsorption of single Cu atom, the conduction band minimum (CBM) and the valence band maximum (VBM) of MoSSe move downward significantly [23], yielding the slightly smaller indirect band gap of 1.61 eV as compared with the slightly larger direct band gap of 1.63 eV without copper adsorption. An impurity level arising from the doped Cu is induced within the forbidden band, about 0.15 eV below CBM. Owing to the narrow impurity level, the electrons of the impurity level could be easily excited to the CB, and thus electrons are largely more conducive to transfer from the VB to the CB with the slightly enhanced conductivity, And the increasing electron transfer is favorable for the consequent catalytic reduction of CO2. Therefore, adsorption of single Cu atom can effectively modify the electronic structure of MoSSe monolayer. To examine the thermodynamic stability of the MoSSe-Cu structure, AIMD simulations were carried out at 300 K. After relaxation for 5 ps, the simulation results were obtained and displayed in Fig. 3 . Despite some structural distortions in the geometrical configuration, MoSSe-Cu basically remains its initial structure with small energy fluctuations, indicating that the structure is stable at room temperature. 3.3 Adsorption and catalytic reduction of CO2 on MoSSe-Cu 3.3.1 Structure of CO2 adsorbed MoSSe-Cu Effective capture of CO2 molecules is the basis and premise for the realization of CO2RR. The adsorption behavior of CO2 molecules on MoSSe-Cu is investigated in this section. Fig. 4 shows the optimized configurations for the adsorption of one CO2 molecule with both the C- and O-bonding modes on Cu. The structural parameters of the original and relaxed systems are listed in Table 1 . From Table 1, compared with gaseous CO2 molecule before adsorption, the Cu-X (X=C and O) bond length shows some increase in the CO2 adsorption system, and the OC-O bond angle declines. As regards the CO2 adsorption systems with distinct Cu-X bonding modes, that with Cu-C bonding mode was found more stable in view of the lower energy and thus taken as the subsequent reaction intermediate. The original straight-line CO2 becomes curved in this adsorption system, indicating that the CO2 molecule is activated. As a result, the CO bonding of CO2 molecule is weakened upon adsorption, which is beneficial for the subsequent catalytic reduction of CO2 to HCOOH. The net charge transfer of CO2 molecule before adsorption on the Cu atom is determined from the Bader charge analysis as C atom losing 2.14 e and each of the O atom accepting 1.07 e. After CO2 adsorption on the Cu atom, C atom loses 1.78 e, and each O atom obtains 1.04 e, while Cu atom loses 0.52 e. These specific values are listed in Table S2. As compared with the case of free CO2 molecule, C atom loses fewer electrons, while each O atom gains almost the same amount of electrons, reflecting that Cu atom gives some electrons to C atom in the adsorption system. To illustrate the charge transfer clearly, the charge density difference (CDD) and the project density of states (PDOS) of the adsorption system are calculated and shown in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively. The increase and decrease of charge are marked in yellow and cyan, respectively, with the isosurface value of 0.003 e/Å3. When CO2 molecule is adsorbed on MoSSe-Cu, the charge density of Cu-C bond increases, associated with the strong bonding interaction. In general, CO2 is weakly adsorbed on Cu surfaces [47–49]. According to Eq. (1), the adsorption energy of CO2 on MoSSe-Cu is calculated as −0.23 eV, in agreement with the previous result (≈ −0.22 eV) for CO2 on the most stable adsorption site of the Cu surface [50]. Further, addition of an extra electron to the system could make CO2 stably adsorb on the Cu atom, indicating that extra electron(s) may enhance the adsorption of CO2 on such adsorbents, as mentioned in the previous work [51]. Meanwhile, the charge density of the CO bond in the adsorbed CO2 molecule declines, and the covalent interaction within the bond is also weakened, which is consistent with the slightly elongated CO bond after adsorption in Table 1. From the spin polarization PDOS of the CO2 adsorbed MoSSe-Cu system in Fig 6, obvious hybridization between Cu 3d orbitals and C 2p orbitals could be found near the Fermi level, reflecting the strong bonding between Cu atom and CO2 molecule in MoSSe-Cu. In addition, the spin-up and spin-down channels of the copper 3d orbitals are asymmetrically distributed, indicating that adsorption of CO2 molecule on MoSSe-Cu may also modify (enhance) the magnetism of the system. In fact, the magnetic moments are calculated as 0.9760 and 0.9955 μB for MoSSe-Cu before and after CO2 adsorption, although both are close to 1 μB. The slight increase of system magnetic moment in the CO2 adsorbed system could be ascribed to the electron transfer from C to Cu, in accordance with the CDD in Fig. 5. The unique asymmetry of Janus MoSSe monolayer leads to the difference in electronegativity between the upper (Se) and lower (S) atoms and generates a built-in electric field. Moreover, the S and Se sides are stretched and compressed, respectively, for MoSSe (a ≈ 3.23 Å) with respect to the conventional MoS2 (a ≈ 3.17 Å [52]) and MoSe2 (a ≈ 3.32 Å [53]), and such asymmetric strain can also contribute to the built-in electric field. In order to clarify the change of the local electrostatic potential energy ΔV in MoSSe before and after adsorption of a Cu atom, the local electrostatic potential energy is calculated as 0.75 eV in pure MoSSe, which is consistent with the previous calculation result (≈ 0.75 eV) [22,54,55]. After adsorption of a Cu atom on Mo top site of the S side, the local electrostatic potential declines moderately (by 20%) to 0.60 eV (see Fig. 7 ), possibly due to the much lower electronegativity of Cu than Mo. It is well known that the built-in electric field may shorten the carrier transport path, accelerate the carrier migration and separation rates, and thus improve the catalytic performance of MoSSe-Cu. However, the reduction of the local electrostatic potential energy ΔV in the single Cu atom adsorbed MoSSe would depress the above carrier acceleration effects due to the decline of the drive. Fortunately, the carrier migration distance is also reduced from 12.6 Å in pure MoSSe to 8.6 Å in MoSSe-Cu, owing to the adsorption of a single copper atom and hence to the consequent modification of the local electronic properties. In view of the two competitive mechanisms, the effective local electric fields are calculated as 0.06 and 0.07 V / Å for MoSSe and MoSSe-Cu, respectively, achieving the obvious increase by about 17%. The above increase in the local electric field arising from the adsorption of a single Cu atom on MoSSe monolayer can suitably account for the enhancement of electrocatalytic activity of the MoSSe-Cu system. 3.3.2 Reaction pathways and Gibbs free energies of CO2 reduction on MoSSe-Cu To obtain insights into the catalytic performance of MoSSe-Cu for CO2RR, the reaction mechanism is further investigated via DFT calculations. For the two-electron reduction of CO2, the main products are CO and HCOOH, with the following reaction pathways: (3) CO2 + 2H+ + 2e− → HCOOH (4) CO2 + 2H+ + 2e− → CO + H2O Here, several possible reaction paths are identified for CO2 reduction to CO and HCOOH on the MoSSe-Cu catalyst. The first elementary reaction step is *CO2 + H+ → *COOH or *OCHO (* represents adsorbed intermediates), in which the activated CO2 molecule generates two intermediates (*COOH and *OCHO) via the proton-coupled electron transfer process. The second reaction step is *COOH + H+ + e− → *CO + *H2O; *OCHO + H+ + e− → *HCOOH. The *CO2 captures a proton/electron pair or the adsorbed H intermediate to form *OCHO with the free energy of −0.78 eV or *COOH with that of −0.10 eV. Thus, *CO2 on the surface of MoSSe-Cu can thermodynamically more easily yield *OCHO, consistent with the previous studies [56]. The adsorption of the *OCHO intermediate is normally believed to be the rate determining step (RDS) for the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to HCOOH [57–59]. The free energies of CO2 reduction to HCOOH by MoSSe-Cu catalyst were calculated and illustrated in Fig. 8 . The CO2-to-HCOOH conversion could be analyzed from three models via the following steps: (a) the adsorption of CO2 molecule on the Cu atom of the MoSSe-Cu catalyst; (b) *CO2 reacts with one electron and one proton to form *OCHO; (c) *OCHO changes into *HCOOH; (d) desorption of HCOOH. From Fig. 8, the formation of *HCOOH is the RDS for the reaction pathway, with the free energy (≈ 0.49 eV) lower than those (≈ 0.86 and 0.57 eV) of the previous studies for the same CO2RR to HCOOH on the similar g-C3N4 and C2N monolayer supported TM trimer catalysts [60,61]. On the other hand, the competing HER, with a bonded *H intermediate [62], can happen on the catalyst during the CO2RR reaction and significantly affect the conversion efficiency of HCOOH. To examine the selectivity of HER in CO2RR, the reaction free energy was calculated for *H formation and shown in Table S1, which was actually 0.55 eV higher than that for *HCOOH formation. So, MoSSe-Cu would prefer to catalyzing the direct reduction of CO2 to HCOOH, and the influence of the competing HER could be ignored. 3.3.3 Mechanisms of catalytic performance of MoSSe-Cu for CO2RR In order to discuss the mechanisms of MoSSe-Cu for the reduction of CO2, the electronic properties could be further analyzed from the above CDD and PDOS here. First, the adsorption of Cu slightly reduces the energy band of MoSSe and prompts the carrier migration. Simultaneously, the unique asymmetric structure of Janus MoSSe and hence the difference in electronegativity between the upper Se layer and the lower S layer may lead to the novel asymmetric charge distribution of the system, creating a built-in electric field. The effective local electric fields of MoSSe and MoSSe-Cu are 0.06 and 0.07 V / Å, respectively, with the increase of about 17% in the latter, which can further accelerate the migration and separation of charge carriers. All the above points are beneficial to the subsequent catalytic reduction of CO2 on MoSSe-Cu. Second, the magnetic moment increases by about 0.02 μB after adsorption of CO2 molecule on MoSSe-Cu, and the Cu 3d orbital is significantly hybridized with the C 2p orbital. As previously reported, the spin polarization occurs at the first electron transfer step in OER, where coherent spin exchange happens between the ferromagnetic catalyst and the adsorbed oxygen species with fast kinetics, under the principle of spin angular momentum conservation [63]. The similar spin polarization would also be expected to occur in the first step of electron transfer in the CO2RR reaction, and the rapid spin charge exchange is obviously accompanied by the magnetic catalyst and the adsorbed carbon. As shown in Fig. 6, Cu(3d104s1) indeed loses a small amount of electron charge after adsorption of CO2. And the cooper 3d – carbon 2p orbital hybridization and hence the spin transfer to Cu may enhance the magnetic moment of the system. At the same time, part of the charge is transferred to the O atom to form the negatively charged *CO2 − ion, which is conducive to the next reactive adsorption of positively charged H +. Finally, the RDS with the free energy of 0.49 eV for reducing CO2 to HCOOH on MoSSe-Cu is also superior to those of 0.86 and 0.50 eV in the previous works [60,64]. Of course, such a low free energy of merely 0.49 eV on MoSSe-Cu would be easily overcome and thus the CO2RR could spontaneously cycle at room temperature. The activated Cu site of the Janus MoSSe-Cu catalyst may regulate the first protonation step of CO2RR and ensure the dominant direct generation of HCOOH, by inhibiting the possibility of other products. Therefore, the MoSSe-Cu catalyst proposed in this work would help to improve the selectivity of formic acid formation in CO2RR. Further, present studies would also provide an isolate evidence for the report by Zheng's team about the modulations of the Cu site for the electrical reduction of CO2 to HCOOH with high selectivity via single atom alloying on Pb-alloy [56]. Their studies indicated that the activated Cu sites of the Pb1Cu catalyst regulate the first protonation step of the CO2RR and divert the CO2RR towards the HCOO* path, thus thwarting the possibility of other products. In addition, our present calculations would also broaden and deepen this point in the field of copper based SACs. 4 Conclusion The catalytic reduction of CO2 is theoretically calculated for the monoatomic Cu adsorbed asymmetric Janus MoSSe monolayer. By MoSSe-Cu catalyst, CO2 is reduced to CO and HCOOH with the two electron transferring process. MoSSe-Cu is more favorable to catalyze the direct reduction of CO2 to HCOOH, with the free energy of 0.49 eV. The mechanisms for the high efficiency of this catalytic reduction would be first ascribed to the modifications of the electronic properties of MoSSe with the adsorption of single Cu atom. Associated with the introduction of the narrow impurity Cu level, the energy band gap is also slightly reduced. After Cu adsorption, the magnetic moment of about 1 μB is induced in the originally non-magnetic system. And the Cu 3d – C 2p orbital hybridization after adsorption of CO2 also effectively promotes spin transfer, leading to the slight magnetic moment increase by 0.02 μB. Second, the internal electric field due to the unique asymmetric structure of MoSSe and the enhancement (by about 17%) of the local electric field in MoSSe-Cu due to the copper adsorption could remarkably accelerate the movement and separation of carriers and ensure the good electrocatalytic performances of the MoSSe-Cu system. Therefore, present MoSSe-Cu would potentially act as an efficient electrocatalyst for the direct reduction of CO2 to HCOOH. coredata.dc:description: Selecting appropriate catalysts to reduce CO2 into C1 and C2 products can effectively alleviate the greenhouse effect. In this work, the catalytic reduction of CO2 on the single Cu atom adsorbed Janus MoSSe monolayer is studied by using DFT calculations. Two electron reduction of CO2 usually yields two products of CO and HCOOH. The adsorption of a single Cu atom on Janus MoSSe monolayer induces the decrease of the band gap and the paramagnetism arising from the copper 3d orbital contribution, which may prompt the catalytic reduction of CO2. Meanwhile, the unique internal electric field due to the novel asymmetric structure of MoSSe and the enhancement (by about 17%) of the local electric field in MoSSe-Cu could significantly accelerate the carrier movement and separation, reflecting the good electrocatalytic performances of MoSSe-Cu system. Here, MoSSe-Cu is more favorable to catalyze the direct reduction of CO2 to HCOOH, with the free energy of merely 0.49 eV for the rate-determining step, indicating that MoSSe-Cu may act as the potential catalyst for reduction of CO2 to HCOOH.
coredata.dc:title: A study on the single atom Cu adsorbed Janus MoSSe monolayer as the catalyst for reduction of CO2 to HCOOH
